Tanzania - Second Integrated Roads and
            Central Transport Corridor and Uganda - First and Second

            Support Technical Assistance Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Integrated Roads
            Project for Tanzania were as follows: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was significant,
            Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and borrower
            performance was Unsatisfactory. Ratings for the Central
            Transport Corridor Project for Tanzania were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was significant, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Ratings for the Roads Sector Institutional
            Support Technical Assistance Project for Uganda were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was high, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Ratings for the First Phase Road
            Development Project for Uganda were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome
            was high, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Ratings
            for the Second Phase Road Development Project for Uganda
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk
            to development outcome was high, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: The
            road agency model has provided sufficient institutional
            capacity in low income countries such as Tanzania and Uganda
            to improve the delivery of new main roads and their
            maintenance. Supporting road funds can further enhance road
            sub-sector reform provided they are properly designed and
            adequately resourced. During road reform initiatives, the
            borrower's absorptive capacity, the degree of
            opposition to change and the time it takes to prepare and
            adopt new legislation, have often been miscalculated by the
            Bank and other development partners. The Bank thus needs to
            ensure appropriate training and skills deployment to i)
            assess and address the borrower's institutional and
            absorptive capacity limitations; ii) gauge the degree of
            resistance to change and make a plan to deal with it, and
            iii) realistically estimate the time it takes to prepare,
            adopt and apply new legislation. An annual assessment of the
            condition and traffic usage of the roads in the network
            enables the decision makers and the public to understand the
            implications of greater or lesser funding.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Central Transport
            Corridor Project for Tanzania were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the monitoring
            and evaluation framework should be comprehensive and
            indicative, showing the path to the project development
            objectives. The output and intermediate indicators should
            closely link and be fully reflective to outcome indicators
            so that the project progress could be closely monitored,
            correct actions could be adopted when necessary. A railway
            cannot compete with road transport for multiple small
            consignments. Such consignments were the core load of
            Tanzania Railway Corporation (TRC) prior to concessioning.
            During the two years of uncertainty between the bidding for
            the concession and the eventual signing of the concession
            agreement with the winning bidder the majority of the load
            was lost to road transport and the concessionaire had no
            chance to win the lost load share back for the railway. In
            the current concession designs, the potential concessionaire
            is faced with obligations to invest in liquidating the
            backlog of maintenance and subsequently maintaining the
            assets in workable conditions. When the infrastructure is in
            very poor condition and heavy investment is required to
            restore the infrastructure to standard condition, then the
            burden on the concessionaire becomes too heavy.

5104860.majtheme: Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Central
            Transport Corridor Project (CTCP) is to: (a) upgrade
            strategic road links; (b) enhance road management capacity;
            and, (c) improve operations of Tanzanian Railways (TRC and
            TAZARA).To this end, through its components the project
            will: 1) upgrade strategic road links, which  includes the
            rehabilitation of 3 different road sections on
            Zanzibar's sea shore, in addition to the Singida-Shelui
            Road (110 km) leading from the region's headquarters,
            to the border of the Tabora region, and, the roads starting
            at Mkwajuni along the coastal valley to Nungwi;
            Matemwe-Pongwe road; Paje-Pingwe road; all three areas of
            strategic tourism importance. In addition, the
            rehabilitation of 5 key ferries is being proposed, subject
            to study recommendations, as well as proposals on the option
            of concessioning to private operators.  The component will
            also finance feasibility studies and detailed engineering
            designs regarding road upgrading; 2) support TANROADS build
            its headquarters in Dar es Salaam, and, will fund civil
            works and supervision. It will assist TANROADS carry out a
            job evaluation, determine the level of staffing and identify
            areas that require strengthening. It will also help them
            identify skills not available within the organization that
            would need to be out-sourced in the short and medium term
            while the organizations makes alternative long term plans.
            Transport studies financed by the component include Dar es
            Salaam Rapid Bus Transit and Traffic Management Study, and
            several studies in the transport sector to cover not only
            roads, but ports and other related aspects. Training and
            technical assistance will be provided; 3) Improve
            infrastructure of the Tanzania Railway Corporation,
            proposing a concession that will include a 25-year lease for
            the TRC railway network, with the right to manage, and
            maintain the network, and lease of TRC locomotives and
            rolling stock. The concessionaire will also have the
            exclusive right on the TRC network to operate freight
            services and passenger services for the period, with an
            obligation to supply designated passenger services.
            Provision of rails, sleepers and other material will be
            supported, while technical assistance, and appropriate
            training will be provided for private sector participation,
            and concessioning issues.

repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Central Transport Corridor Roads
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
In the context of the Central Transport
            Corridor Roads Project, the Singida Shelui Road - connecting
            Dar es Salaam with northwestern Tanzania, and with
            landlocked Rwanda, Burundi, and eastern Congo - will be
            upgraded to bitumen standards, to include drainage systems,
            bypassing the hilly section of Sekenke (which cuts across a
            dense forest) so as to prevent deforesation. In order to
            extend sustainable rural production to the road influence,
            promote access, and lower transport costs, the road
            improvements would enhance socioeconomic development,
            including the tourism sector. However, adverse environmental
            impacts, such as soil erosion, loss of farmland, wildlife,
            and natural habitats, as well as air, water and soil
            pollution, in addition to safety and health hazards, call
            for an environmental management to mitigate adversity, as
            follows. To minimize impacts on wildlife, and forests,
            sensitive areas should be realigned by separating road and
            forest with green barriers, and, providing road crossings
            for wildlife by smoothing embankment slopes at regular
            distances, opening river weirs, and large culverts in
            swamplands. The road design should blend in with the
            landscape, avoiding cuts as possible, but stabilizing
            necessary cuts with protective walls, favoring
            re-vegetation. Culverts and cross-drainage should be
            designed to maintain the hydraulic balance, including borrow
            pit excavation and restoration, to avoid stagnation. Soil
            erosion, sedimentation in drainage lines, and cascade
            effects in drains can be minimized by paving drain outlet
            areas with stones and concrete. Road safety measures should
            be in place, as well as the creation of green barriers to
            reduce dust and gas exhaustions.

Tanzania - Central Transport Corridor Roads
            Project : environmental assessment

repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Central Transport Corridor Roads
            Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Central Transport Corridor Roads
            Project, aims at extending sustainable rural production to
            the road influence, to promote access, and lower transport
            costs. To this end, the Singida Shelui Road - connecting Dar
            es Salaam with northwestern Tanzania, and with landlocked
            Rwanda, Burundi, and eastern Congo - will be upgraded to
            bitumen standards (including drainage systems), bypassing
            the hilly section of Sekenke (which cuts across a dense
            forest) so as to prevent deforesation. Nevertheless,
            implementation of the project, namely the Singida Shelui
            Road upgrade, will have negative impacts on the people
            living in, or in the proximity of major towns and villages
            along the route. Relocation will be necessary of both
            residential buildings, businesses or community facilities,
            and farms. This resettlement action plan aims at improving,
            or at least restoring, the livelihoods of project affected
            people (PAP) to their current living standards. Following
            community consultations, compensation will be provided as
            follows: real estate losses will be paid at market values;
            business and income losses will be paid, based on assessed
            monthly net profits evidenced by audit accounts, multiplied
            by thirty six months; agricultural land losses will be paid
            at replacement costs, or in cash compensations, while crop
            losses will be compensated on estimated market values. The
            costs of relocation, and moving expenses will be covered,
            and, grievance mechanisms will be in place should complaints
            trigger the need for dispute resolution.

            Project : resettlement plan
